'''Eurostar''' is a [[high-speed rail]]way service connecting [[London]] with [[Amsterdam]], [[Avignon]], [[Brussels]], [[Lille]], [[Lyon]], [[Marseille]], [[Paris]] and [[Rotterdam]]. All its trains traverse the [[Channel Tunnel]] between the [[United Kingdom]] and [[France]], owned and operated separately by [[Getlink]].

The London terminus is [[St Pancras railway station|St Pancras International]], the other British calling points being [[Ebbsfleet International railway station|Ebbsfleet International]] and [[Ashford International railway station|Ashford International]] in Kent. Intermediate calling points in France are [[Gare de Calais-Fréthun|Calais-Fréthun]] and [[Gare de Lille-Europe|Lille-Europe]], with trains to Paris terminating at [[Gare du Nord]]. Trains to Belgium terminate at [[Brussels-South railway station|Midi/Zuid station]] in Brussels. The only intermediate calling point in the [[Netherlands]] is [[Rotterdam Centraal station|Rotterdam Centraal]], with trains terminating at [[Amsterdam Centraal station|Amsterdam Centraal]]. In addition, there are limited services from London to [[Disneyland Paris]] at [[Gare de Marne-la-Vallée - Chessy|Marne-la-Vallée – Chessy]], direct services to southern France (Lyon, Avignon and Marseille) from May to September<ref>https://content-static.eurostar.com/documents/UK_timetable.pdf</ref> (launched on 1 May 2015), and seasonal direct services to the French Alps in winter (December to April).

The service is operated by eighteen-car [[British Rail Class 373|Class 373/1 trains]] and sixteen-car {{BRC|374}} trains which run at up to {{convert|300|km/h|mph|0}} on a network of high-speed lines. The [[LGV Nord]] line in France opened before Eurostar services began in 1994, and newer lines enabling faster journeys were added later—[[HSL 1]] in Belgium and [[High Speed 1]] in southern England. The French and Belgian parts of the network are shared with Paris–Brussels [[Thalys]] services and also with [[TGV]] trains. In the United Kingdom the two-stage [[High Speed 1|Channel Tunnel Rail Link]] project was completed on 14 November 2007 and renamed ''High Speed 1'', when the London terminus of Eurostar changed from [[Waterloo International railway station|Waterloo International]] to [[St Pancras railway station|St Pancras International]].

Until 2010, Eurostar was operated jointly by the national railway companies of France and Belgium, [[SNCF]] and [[SNCB/NMBS]], and [[Eurostar (UK) Ltd]] (EUKL), a subsidiary of [[London and Continental Railways]] (LCR), which also owned the high-speed infrastructure and stations on the British side. Eurostar has become the dominant operator on the routes that it operates, carrying more passengers than all airlines combined. Other operators have expressed an interest in starting competing services following deregulation in 2010. On 1 September 2010, Eurostar was incorporated as a single corporate entity called [[Eurostar International Limited]] (EIL), replacing the joint operation between EUKL, SNCF and SNCB/NMBS.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.breakingtravelnews.com/news/article/eurostar-confirms-plans-for-senior-management-changes/ |title= Eurostar confirms plans for senior management changes |work=Breaking Travel News |date=20 August 2009}}</ref> EIL is owned by [[SNCF]] (55%), [[Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec]] (CDPQ) (30%), [[Hermes Infrastructure]] (10%) and [[NMBS/SNCB|NMBS]] (5%).<ref name="bbc-20150304-sale">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-31721334 |title=UK government sells Eurostar stake for £757.1m |work=BBC News Online |date=4 March 2015 |accessdate=4 March 2015 |quote=Patina Rail LLP will acquire the UK Treasury's entire share … consortium is made up of two companies: Canadian-based Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec (CDPQ) and the UK's Hermes Infrastructure … will own 30% and 10% of Eurostar respectively}}</ref><ref name="eurostar.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.eurostar.com/uk-en/about-eurostar/our-company/behind-the-scenes|title=Behind the scenes - Eurostar |publisher= }}</ref><ref name="realestate.ipe.com">{{cite web |url=https://realestate.ipe.com/news/infrastructure/hermes-secures-eurostar-ownership-for-pension-funds-after-uk-sell-off/10006975.fullarticle|title=Hermes secures Eurostar ownership for pension funds after UK sell-off |publisher= }}</ref>

In June 2014, the UK shareholding in Eurostar International Limited was transferred from London and Continental Railways / [[Department for Transport]] to [[HM Treasury]].<ref>{{cite web |title=House of Commons Hansard Ministerial Statements for 19 Jun 2014 (pt 0001) |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201415/cmhansrd/cm140619/wmstext/140619m0001.htm |website=UK Parliament |publisher=House of Commons |accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> That October, it was announced that the UK government planned to raise £300 million by selling that stake.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-29588412 |title=Eurostar rail stake touted for sale by UK government |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref> In March 2015, the UK government announced that it would be selling its 40% share to an Anglo-Canadian consortium made up of Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec and Hermes Infrastructure. This sale was completed in May 2015.<ref name="eurostar.com"/>

==History==

===Conception and planning===
{{main |Channel Tunnel |Getlink |TransManche Link}}
[[File:Eurotunnel schema (empty service).svg|thumb|A typical Channel Tunnel cross section. A service tunnel lies in between the twin rail tunnels.]]
The history of Eurostar can be traced to the 1986 choice of a rail tunnel to provide a cross-channel link between Britain and France.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.jrtr.net/jrtr26/pdf/f38_nou.pdf |title=The Channel Tunnel |last=Noulton |first=John |journal=Japan Railway & Transport Review |date=February 2001 |issue=26 |pages=38–45 |accessdate=10 May 2009}}</ref> A previous attempt to construct a tunnel between the two nations had begun in 1974, but was quickly aborted. Construction began on a new basis in 1988. [[Getlink|Eurotunnel]] was created to manage and own the tunnel, which was finished in 1993, the official opening taking place in May 1994.<ref name="BBC openingceremony"/>

In addition to the tunnel's [[Eurotunnel Shuttle|shuttle trains]] carrying cars and lorries between [[Folkestone]] and [[Calais]], the decision to build a railway tunnel opened up the possibility of through passenger and freight train services between places further afield.<ref name='EuroTun His'>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurotunnel.com/ukcP3Main/ukcCorporate/ukcTunnelInfrastructure/ukcDevelopment/ukpHistory |title=Our history |publisher=Eurotunnel |accessdate=10 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123153410/http://www.eurotunnel.com/ukcP3Main/ukcCorporate/ukcTunnelInfrastructure/ukcDevelopment/ukpHistory |archivedate=23 November 2010}}</ref> [[British Rail]] and SNCF contracted with Eurotunnel to use half the tunnel's capacity for this purpose. In 1987, Britain, France and Belgium set up an International Project Group to specify a train to provide an international high-speed passenger service through the tunnel. France had been operating high-speed TGV services since 1981, and had begun construction of a new high-speed line between Paris and the Channel Tunnel, LGV Nord; French TGV technology was chosen as the basis for the new trains. An order for 30 trainsets, to be manufactured in France but with some British and Belgian components, was placed in December 1989.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} On 20 June 1993, the first Eurostar test train travelled through the tunnel to the UK.<ref name = "Eurost His"/> Various technical difficulties in running the new trains on British tracks were quickly overcome.<ref name="Eurobreakdown"/>

===Launch of service===
[[File:Eurostar.svg|thumb|left|200px|Eurostar logo 1994–2011]]
On 14 November 1994, Eurostar services began between [[Waterloo International]] station in London, Gare du Nord in Paris and Brussels-South railway station in Brussels.<ref name="EuroTun His"/><ref name = 'waterloovid'>{{cite web |url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=Whnt8cYaNng&feature=channel |title=Official Waterloo 'Goodbye' video, useful statistics and numbers shown |publisher=Youtube.com |date=20 December 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2010}}</ref><ref name = 'Watlooguardi'>{{cite news |title= Waterloo International: 1994–2007 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/gallery/2007/nov/13/railtravel?picture=331254132 |work = The Guardian |location = London |date=13 November 2007 |accessdate=18 November 2007}}</ref> The train service started with a limited ''Discovery'' service; the full daily service started from 28 May 1995.<ref name="Rail Chronology: Eurostar services">{{cite web |url=http://www.railchronology.free-online.co.uk/Eurostar.htm |title=Rail Chronology: Eurostar services |website=www.railchronology.free-online.co.uk}}</ref>

In 1995, Eurostar was achieving an average end-to-end speed of {{convert|171.5|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} between London and Paris.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.jrtr.net/jrtr40/pdf/f04_tak.pdf |title= High-speed Railways:The last ten years |last=Takagi |first=Ryo |journal=Japan Railway & Transport Review |issue=40 |pages=4–7 |date=March 2005 |accessdate=1 May 2009}}</ref>
On 8 January 1996, Eurostar launched services from a second UK railway station when Ashford International was opened.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/about_eurostar/press_release/press_archive_2006/09_01_06_Eurostar_celebrates_10_years.jsp |title= Eurostar celebrates 10 years at Ashford International |publisher= Eurostar |date= 9 January 2006 |accessdate= <!---- 25 April 2009-----> |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120522090109/http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/about_eurostar/press_release/press_archive_2006/09_01_06_Eurostar_celebrates_10_years.jsp |archive-date= 22 May 2012 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref>

On 23 September 2003, passenger services began running on the first completed section of High Speed 1.<ref name="Eurost His"/> Following a high-profile glamorous opening ceremony<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/the-royal-pride-of-reborn-st-pancras-6680267.html |title= The royal pride of reborn St Pancras |last= Carmichael |first=Sri |author2=Low, Valentine |newspaper= London Evening Standard |date=7 November 2007 |accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref> and a large advertising campaign,<ref>{{cite news |last= Sweney |first=Mark |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/nov/14/advertising1 |title=Eurostar launches St Pancras ads |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=14 July 2007 |accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref> on 14 November 2007, Eurostar services in London transferred from Waterloo to the extended and extensively refurbished [[St Pancras International]].<ref name="transpancras"/>
{{clear left}}

===Records achieved===
[[File:Faster Tomorrow.jpg|thumb|left|Eurostar relocated from [[Waterloo International railway station|Waterloo International station]] to [[St Pancras International railway station|St Pancras International station]] in 2007.]]
The Channel Tunnel used by Eurostar services holds the record for having the longest undersea section anywhere in the world,<ref name="Daily Post 2006">{{cite news |first= Jane |last= Gilbert |title= 'Chunnel' workers link France and Britain |work= The Daily Post |location = Rotorua, New Zealand |publisher= APN New Zealand |date= 1 December 2006}}</ref> and it is the second-longest rail tunnel in the world.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,,21153042-5013280,00.html |last = Minus |first=Jodie |accessdate=27 May 2009 |title=Eurostar an underground force |work = The Australian |location = Sydney |date=26 January 2007}}</ref>

On 30 July 2003, a Eurostar train set a new British [[List of vehicle speed records|speed record]] of {{convert|334.7|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} on the first section of the "High Speed 1" railway through the Channel Tunnel,<ref name="Eurost His" /><ref name="waterloovid" /> two months before official services began running.

On 16 May 2006, Eurostar set a new record for the longest non-stop high-speed journey, a distance of {{convert|1421|km|mi}} from [[London]] to [[Cannes]] taking 7 hours 25 minutes.<ref>{{cite press release |url= https://www.eurostar.com/uk-en/about-eurostar/press-office/press-releases/2006/eurostar-sets-new-guinness-world-record-with-cast |title=Eurostar sets new Guinness World Record with cast and filmmakers of Columbia Pictures' The Da Vinci Code |publisher = Eurostar |date=17 June 2006 |accessdate =27 May 2009}}</ref>

On 4 September 2007, a record-breaking train left Paris Gare du Nord at 10:44 (09:44 [[British Summer Time|BST]]) and reached London St Pancras in 2 hours 3 minutes 39 seconds;<ref>{{cite press release
|url=http://www.eriksrailnews.com/archive/eurostar_ctrl_pr.html |accessdate=<!---12 April 2007--->
|title=Eurostar breaks UK high speed record |publisher =Eurostar |date=30 July 2003}}</ref> carrying journalists and railway workers. This record trip was also the first passenger-carrying arrival to the new [[St Pancras railway station|St Pancras International station]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6977211.stm |title=Eurostar sets Paris-London record |work= BBC News |date=4 September 2007 |accessdate =14 December 2007}}</ref>

On 20 September 2007, Eurostar broke another record when it completed the journey from Brussels to London in 1 hour, 43 minutes.<ref>{{cite news
|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/eurostar-puts-brussels-within-the-twohour-club-after-record-rail-journey-403044.html |title=Eurostar puts Brussels within the 'two-hour club' after record rail journey |newspaper = The Independent |location=London |last = Williams |first=Michael |date= 21 September 2007}}</ref>

===Regional Eurostar and Nightstar===
[[File:Eurostars at waterloo international.jpg|thumb|left|A pair of Eurostar trains at the former [[Waterloo International railway station|Waterloo International]]]]
{{Further|Regional Eurostar |Nightstar (train)}}
The original proposals for Eurostar included direct services to Paris and Brussels from cities north of London (NoL): [[Manchester]] via [[Birmingham]] on the [[West Coast Main Line]] and on the [[East Coast Main Line]] [[Leeds]] and [[Glasgow]] via [[Edinburgh]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] and [[York]].<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101214082434/http://dft.gov.uk/pgr/rail/passenger/europe/reviewofregionaleurostarserv3325?page=10 |archivedate=14 December 2010 |date=n.d. |url= http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/rail/passenger/europe/reviewofregionaleurostarserv3325?page=10 |title= Review of regional Eurostar services: summary report |publisher= [[Department for Transport]]}}</ref> Seven shorter "NoL" Eurostar trains for these [[Regional Eurostar]] services were built, but these services never ran. Predicted journey times of almost nine hours for Glasgow to Paris at the time of growth of [[Low-cost carrier|low-cost air travel]] during the 1990s made the plans commercially unviable against the cheaper and quicker airlines.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/the_economy/330888.stm |title= Eurostar extension in doubt |work=BBC News |date=28 April 1999 |accessdate=31 December 2007}}</ref> Other reasons that have been suggested for these services having never been run were both government policies and the disruptive [[privatisation of British Rail]].<ref name= 'regionfail'>{{cite journal |jstor=20003928 |last1=Knowles |first1=Richard |last2=Farrington |first2=John |title=Why Has the Market Not Been Created for Channel Tunnel Regional Passenger Rail Services? |journal=Area |volume=30 |issue=4 |pages=359–366 |publisher=Royal Geographical Society |date=December 1998 |doi=10.1111/j.1475-4762.1998.tb00080.x}}</ref>
Three of the Regional Eurostar units were leased by [[Great North Eastern Railway]] (GNER) to increase domestic services from [[London King's Cross railway station|London King's Cross]] to York and later [[Leeds]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1763438.stm |date=16 January 2002 |title= High-speed GNER trains scrapped |work= BBC News |accessdate=10 May 2009}}</ref> The leases ended in December 2005, and most of the NoL sets have since been transferred to SNCF for TGV services in northern France.<ref name = 'CTRLrailtec'>{{cite web |url= http://www.railway-technology.com/projects/chunnel/ |title= Channel Tunnel Rail Link (CTRL), United Kingdom |publisher=Railway-technology-com |date=n.d. |accessdate=11 May 2009}}</ref>

An international [[Nightstar (train)|Nightstar]] sleeper train was also planned; this would have travelled the same routes as Regional Eurostar, plus the [[Great Western Main Line]] to [[Cardiff]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.railwatch.org.uk/backtrack/rw098/rw098p10.pdf |title=Second chance for Eurostar sleepers |last=Guerra |first=Michael |issue=93 |date=December 2003 |pages=10–11 |work=Railwatch |publisher=RailFuture |accessdate=28 April 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620081753/http://www.railwatch.org.uk/backtrack/rw098/rw098p10.pdf |archive-date=20 June 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> These were also deemed commercially unviable, and the scheme was abandoned with no services ever operated. In 2000, the coaches were sold to [[Via Rail]] in Canada.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1215/is_8_204/ai_108114496/pg_2/?tag=content;col1 |title=Via Rail's renaissance: "Renaissance" is the name Via Rail Canada has given its new fleet of European-built passenger cars, but it applies equally well to the entire operation |date=August 2003 |last=Middleton |first=William D. |location=New York |newspaper=Railway Age |accessdate=19 June 2009}}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Hickling |first= Michael |url= http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/features/Fast-track-to-Europe-.3439321.jp |title=Fast track to Europe – old track to Yorkshire |work= Yorkshire Post |location= Leeds |date=1 November 2007}}</ref>

===Ashford International station===
[[File:Ashford International Station 01.JPG|thumb|right |Domestic entrance to [[Ashford International]], since 2007]]
{{main |Ashford International railway station}}
Ashford International station was the original station for Eurostar services in Kent.<ref>{{cite web
 |url          = http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/travel_information/at_the_station/stations/ashford_international.jsp
 |title        = Official Ashford International information page
 |publisher    = Eurostar
 |accessdate   = 8 May 2009
 |archive-url  = https://web.archive.org/web/20090221122743/http://eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/travel_information/at_the_station/stations/ashford_international.jsp
 |archive-date = 21 February 2009
 |dead-url     = yes
 |df           = dmy-all
}}</ref>
Once Ebbsfleet International railway station, also designed to serve the [[Kent]] region, had opened, only three trains a day to Paris and one to Disneyland Paris called at Ashford for a considerable amount of time. There were fears that services at Ashford International might be further reduced or withdrawn altogether as Eurostar planned to make Ebbsfleet the new regional hub instead.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saveashfordinternational.org.uk/ |title=Save Ashford International |work=www.saveashfordinternational.org.uk |accessdate=18 February 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080113045703/http://saveashfordinternational.org.uk/ |archivedate = 13 January 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
| url=http://www.metro.co.uk/home/article.html?in_article_id=19616&in_page_id=1 |title=Ashford to become a 'ghost town' |work=Metro |date=12 September 2006}}</ref> However, after a period during which no Brussels trains served the station,<ref>{{cite news |date=12 September 2006 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/eurostar-cutbacks-deliver-blow-to-ashford-415646.html |title=Eurostar cutbacks deliver blow to Ashford |work=The Independent |first=Michael |last=Harrison |location=London}}</ref> to the dissatisfaction of the local communities,<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/5337586.stm |title= New station means Eurostar change |work= BBC News |date=12 September 2006 |accessdate=14 December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/6520691.stm |title=Petition opposing Eurostar cuts |work=BBC News |date=3 April 2007 |accessdate=6 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/6090558.stm |title=Town fears losing Eurostar trains |work = BBC News |date=27 October 2006 |accessdate=4 January 2010}}</ref> Eurostar re-introduced a single daily Ashford-Brussels service on 23 February 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/travel_information/before_you_go/ashford_brussels/ashford_to_brussels.jsp |title=Ashford International to Brussels |publisher=Eurostar |accessdate=2 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090130030911/http://eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/travel_information/before_you_go/ashford_brussels/ashford_to_brussels.jsp |archivedate=30 January 2009 |df=dmy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ryeandbattleobserver.co.uk/newsrbo/Rye-back-on-internationall-rail.4371290.jp |title=Rye back on international rail map |newspaper=Rye and Battle Observer |accessdate=8 August 2008 |first=Andy |last=Hemsley}}</ref>

===Rules for cycles on trains===
In 2015, Eurostar threatened to require that cyclists dismantle bicycles before they could be transported on trains. Following criticism from [[Boris Johnson]] and cycling groups, Eurostar reversed the edict.<ref><https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-34815867</ref>

===Wi-Fi and onboard entertainment===
By March 2016. onboard entertainment was provided by [[GoMedia]], including Wi-Fi connectivity and up to 300 hours of movies and television kept on the train's servers and accessed using the passenger's own devices: mobile phones, tablets etc. A tracker app allows customers to see where they are.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2016/03/16/bring-your-own-device-to-eurostar-entertainment/ |title= Bring your own device to Eurostar entertainment |author=Julian Glover |date=16 March 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2016}}</ref>

==Mainline routes==
{{Eurostar}}

===LGV Nord===
{{main |LGV Nord}}
[[File:Networks of Major High Speed Rail Operators in Europe.gif|left|thumb|250px|Networks of Major High Speed Rail Operators in Europe. Eurostar line network shown in brown.]]
LGV Nord is a French {{convert|333|km|adj=on}}-long [[high-speed rail]] line that connects Paris to the Belgian border and the Channel Tunnel via [[Lille]]. It opened in 1993.<ref>{{Link language|fr}}{{cite web |url=http://www.cgedd.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/LGV_Nord_cle58b46b.pdf |title=Bilan LOTI de la LGV Nord Rapport |date=May 2005 |publisher=Réseau Ferré de France |accessdate=10 May 2009}}</ref>
Its extensions to Belgium and towards Paris, as well as connecting to the Channel Tunnel, have made LGV Nord a part of every Eurostar journey undertaken. A Belgian high-speed line, HSL 1, was added to the end of LGV Nord, at the Belgian border, in 1997. Of all French high-speed lines, LGV Nord sees the widest variety of high-speed rolling stock and is quite busy; a proposed cut-off bypassing Lille, which would reduce Eurostar journey times to Paris, is called [[LGV Picardie]].

===Channel Tunnel===
{{main |Channel Tunnel}}
The Channel Tunnel is a crucial part of the route as it is the only rail connection between Great Britain and the European mainland. It joins LGV Nord in France with High Speed One in Britain. Tunnelling began in 1988, and the {{convert|50.5|km|adj=on}} tunnel was officially opened by British sovereign [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] and the French President [[François Mitterrand]] at a ceremony in Calais on 6 May 1994.<ref name="BBC openingceremony">{{cite news |title=On this day: 6 May 1994: President and Queen open Chunnel (with video clip) |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/6/newsid_2511000/2511653.stm |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008 |date=6 May 1994}}</ref>
It is owned by [[Getlink]], which charges a significant toll to Eurostar for its use.<ref name="Eurotoll">{{cite news |title=Fees for high-speed tunnel link derail Eurostar's gravy train |last=O'Connell |first=Dominic |url= http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/transport/article3671706.ece |work=The Times |location=London |date=13 March 2008 |accessdate=25 May 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612141213/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/transport/article3671706.ece|archivedate=12 June 2011}}</ref>
In 1996, the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]] named the tunnel as one of the [[American Society of Civil Engineers#World wonders of the Modern World|Seven Wonders of the Modern World]].<ref name="The Plain Dealer">{{cite news |first= Christopher |last= Reynolds |title=Seven Wonders of the World: The Modern List |work=The Plain Dealer |location=Cleveland, Ohio |date=19 May 1996}}</ref>
Along the current route of the Eurostar service, line speeds are {{convert|300|km/h|mph|0}} except within the Channel Tunnel, where a reduced speed of {{convert|160|km/h|mph|sigfig=1}} applies for safety reasons.<ref name = 'railfaneurostar'>{{cite web |url= http://www.railfaneurope.net/tgv/eurostar.html |title=Eurostar article |publisher=railfaneurope.net |date=27 May 2001 |accessdate=28 April 2009}}</ref><ref name="eurotunnrules">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurotunnel.com/NR/rdonlyres/116B61C1-A669-4503-872C-FA1356B38F1F/0/DRR_NS_2008_EN_Final.pdf |title=Eurotunnel Network Statement 2008 |publisher=Eurotunnel |accessdate=7 April 2012 |date=18 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081125022335/http://www.eurotunnel.com/NR/rdonlyres/116B61C1-A669-4503-872C-FA1356B38F1F/0/DRR_NS_2008_EN_Final.pdf |archivedate=25 November 2008}}</ref>
Since the launch of Eurostar services, severe disruptions and cancellations have been caused by fires breaking out within the Channel Tunnel, such as in [[1996 Channel Tunnel fire|1996]],<ref name="Kirkland fire">{{cite journal |author=Kirkland, C.J. |year=2002 |title=The fire in the Channel Tunnel |journal=Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology |volume=17 |pages=129–132 |url=http://www.ita-aites.org/cms/fileadmin/filemounts/ovion/doc/safety/sydney/OS12.PDF |doi=10.1016/S0886-7798(02)00014-7 |issue=2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100920093906/http://www.ita-aites.org/cms/fileadmin/filemounts/ovion/doc/safety/sydney/OS12.PDF |archivedate=20 September 2010 |df=dmy}}</ref> [[Channel Tunnel#Fires|2006]] (minor),<ref name="BBC fire">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/5271784.stm |title=Lorry fire closes Channel Tunnel |work=BBC News |date=21 August 2006 |accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref> [[2008 Channel Tunnel fire|2008]] and 2015.<ref name = "Tunnelfire"/>

===HSL 1===
{{main |HSL 1}}
[[File:Eurostar by Silly.jpg|thumb|left|Eurostar on the HSL 1]]
[[File:Eurostar in Tournai.jpg|thumb|Eurostar passing [[Tournai railway station|Tournai]] on the Belgian classic line]]
Until the opening on 2 June 1996, of the first phase of the Belgian high speed line,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://users.telenet.be/pk/lijnen.htm#1|title=Belgische spoorlijnen|website=users.telenet.be}}</ref> Eurostar trains were routed via the [[Belgian railway line 94]]. The Eurostar routes still use the line as a diversion if engineering works are taking place on HSL1, depending where it is. The 06:13 from London St Pancras to Brussels still uses the line as a diversion to bypass the peak time disruptions on HSL1 due to the extra TGV services from Brussels for the commuters. After 2 June 1996, some Eurostars to Brussels were routed via the first phase of the Belgian High Speed line and the Belgian railway line 78 via [[Mons]]. Although this line is still as a diversion if HSL1 is doing engineering, also depending where the maintenance is taking place.<ref name="Rail Chronology: Eurostar services"/> Journey times between London and Brussels were improved when an {{convert|88|km|mi|adj=on}} Belgian high-speed line, [[HSL 1]], opened on 14 December 1997.<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://ecms.b-holding.be/DMS/ds/en/1902728 |date=14 December 2007 |title=Infrabel celebrates 10 years of the High Speed Line in Belgium |format=DOC |publisher=[[Infrabel]] |location=Brussels |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303221532/https://ecms.b-holding.be/DMS/ds/en/1902728 |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.fte2.org/doc/car/ctr.pdf |title=Detailed map layout of Belgian railway transportation network |publisher=[[Infrabel]] |accessdate=13 May 2009}}</ref> It links with LGV Nord on the border with France, allowing Eurostar trains heading to Brussels to make the transition between the two without having to reduce speed. A further four-minute improvement for London–Brussels trains was achieved in December 2006, with the opening of the {{convert|435|m|ft|adj=on}} [[Brussels South Viaduct]].<ref>{{cite press release |url = http://www.eurostar.com/UK/be/leisure/about_eurostar/press_release/press_archive_2006/01_12_2006_viaduct_brussels.jsp |title = New £7.5 million railway viaduct at Brussels Midi station further enhances Eurostar reliability on the London–Brussels route |publisher=Eurostar |accessdate=16 April 2009 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110607011500/http://www.eurostar.com/UK/be/leisure/about_eurostar/press_release/press_archive_2006/01_12_2006_viaduct_brussels.jsp |archive-date=7 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Linking the international platforms of Brussels-South railway station with the high-speed line, the viaduct separates Eurostar (and Thalys) from local services.

===High Speed 1===
[[File:StroodCTRL2.JPG|thumb|right| A Eurostar train passing [[Strood]], on approach to the Medway bridge]]
{{main |High Speed 1}}
High Speed 1 (HS1), formerly known as the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (CTRL), is a {{convert|108|km|adj=on}} high-speed railway line running from London through [[Kent]] to the British end of the Channel Tunnel.<ref name = 'railtechhs10'>{{cite news |url = http://www.railway-technology.com/projects/highspeedone/ |title = High Speed 1, United Kingdom |publisher=railway-technology.com |accessdate =11 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/rail/pi/ctrl/theneedforachanneltunnelrailli1 |title=The need for a Channel Tunnel Rail Link |publisher=[[Department for Transport]] |accessdate=10 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080613165413/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/rail/pi/ctrl/theneedforachanneltunnelrailli1 |archivedate=13 June 2008 |df=dmy}}</ref>
It was built in two stages. The first section between the tunnel and [[Fawkham Junction]] in north Kent opened in September 2003, cutting London–Paris journey times by 21 minutes to 2 hours 35 minutes, and London–Brussels to 2 hours 20 minutes. On 14 November 2007, commercial services began over the whole of the new HS1 line. The redeveloped St Pancras International station became the new London [[terminal train station|terminus]] for all Eurostar services.<ref name="bbc20071114">{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/7093761.stm
|title= Eurostar arrives in Paris on time |work= BBC News |date=14 November 2007 |accessdate=14 December 2007}}</ref>
The completion of High Speed 1 has brought the British part of Eurostar's route up to the same standards as the French and Belgian high-speed lines. Non-stop journey times were reduced by a further 20 minutes to 2 hours 15 minutes for London–Paris and 1 hour 51 minutes for London–Brussels.<ref name = 'alstomhs1'>{{cite press release |url=http://www.transport.alstom.com/pr_transp_v2/2007/33632.EN.php?languageId=EN&dir=/pr_transp_v2/2007/&idRubriqueCourante=13931 |title=With the new Eurostar high speed rail link, Alstom participates in the European rail network |date=7 November 2007 |publisher = [[Alstom]] |accessdate=<!---10 May 2009--->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/travel/destinations/europe/article2744141.ece |title=Eurostar to Brussels |last=Rudd |first=Matt |work = The Times |location = London |date= 28 October 2007 |accessdate=10 May 2009}}</ref>

==Services==

===Frequency===
[[File:Eurostar departure information - Brussels.JPG|thumb|left|Eurostar departure information – Brussels]]
Eurostar offers up to sixteen weekday London – Paris services (eighteen on Fridays) including ten non-stop (twelve on Fridays). Previously there were ten London–Lille and Brussels services, including five running non-stop as far as Lille, but this has now been reduced to seven each way.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurostar.com/pdf/timetables/UK_timetable%281%29.pdf |title=Eurostar Service from 9 December 2012 to 1 June 2013 |publisher=Eurostar |accessdate=22 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316051616/http://www.eurostar.com/pdf/timetables/UK_timetable%281%29.pdf |archivedate=16 March 2012 |df=dmy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/destinations.jsp |title=Destinations |publisher=Eurostar |accessdate=15 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090627013836/http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/destinations.jsp |archive-date=27 June 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In addition, there is a return trip from London to [[Gare de Marne-la-Vallée - Chessy|Marne-la-Vallée - Chessy]] for [[Disneyland Resort Paris|Disneyland Paris]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.travelempire.co.uk/disneyresort_byeurostar.phtml?gclid=CMayyNSahbMCFYTMtAodq0UA7Q |title= Disneyland by Eurostar- Travel Empire |accessdate=16 October 2012}}</ref> which runs at least 4 times a week with increased frequency during school holidays, and an up-to-5-times-a-week service to Marseille via Lyon and Avignon. There are also seasonal services in the winter. "Snow trains",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurostar.com/static/micro_site/eurostar_snow_train.htm |title=Eurostar Snow Train |work=Eurostar website |accessdate=16 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121210031016/http://www.eurostar.com/static/micro_site/eurostar_snow_train.htm |archivedate=10 December 2012 |df=dmy}}</ref> aimed at skiers, to [[Bourg-Saint-Maurice]], [[La Plagne|Aime-la-Plagne]] and [[Moûtiers]] in the [[Alps]]; these run twice-weekly, one overnight and one during the daytime.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisfrenchlife.com/thisfrenchlife/2008/07/eurostar-winter.html |title= Eurostar winter ski tickets |work = thisfrenchlife.com |accessdate=11 May 2009}}</ref> Intermediate stations are Ebbsfleet International in northwest Kent, Ashford International in southeast Kent, and [[Gare de Calais-Fréthun|Calais-Fréthun]] and Lille-Europe in Nord-Pas-de-Calais.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurostar.com/UK/be/leisure/about_eurostar/on_the_move/other_uk_stations.jsp |title=Eurostar's other UK stations |publisher=Eurostar |accessdate=11 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925173312/http://www.eurostar.com/UK/be/leisure/about_eurostar/on_the_move/other_uk_stations.jsp |archive-date=25 September 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> In February 2018, Eurostar announced the start of its long planned service from London to Amsterdam, with an initial two trains per day from April of that year running between St Pancras and [[Amsterdam Centraal station|Amsterdam Centraal]]. This launched as a one-way service, with return trains carrying passengers to Rotterdam and Brussels Midi/Zuid, making a 28-minute stop (which has not been deemed long enough to process UK-bound passengers) and then carrying different passengers from Brussels to London.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.seat61.com/trains-and-routes/direct-eurostar-london-to-amsterdam.htm|title=Direct Eurostar from London to Amsterdam - Starts 4 April 2018 - 
Timetable, fares, tickets|author=|date=|website=www.seat61.com}}</ref> Passengers travelling back must take [[Thalys]] services to Brussels Midi/Zuid where they can join the Eurostar. This is owing to the lack of [[UK Border Force]] facilities at Amsterdam Centraal and Rotterdam Centraal.

Since 14 November 2007, all Eurostar trains have been routed via High Speed 1 to or from the redeveloped London terminus at St Pancras International, which at a cost of £800 million was extensively rebuilt and extended to cope with {{convert|394|m|yd|adj=on}} long Eurostar trains.<ref name = 'transpancras'>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7079915.stm |title=The transformation of St Pancras |work= BBC News |date=6 November 2007
|last= Higham |first=Nick |accessdate=14 December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/eurostar/738722/Eurostar-will-cross-London---in-15-hours.html
|title=Eurostar will cross London — in 15 hours |work= The Daily Telegraph |location= London |last=Millward |first=David |date=3 November 2007 |accessdate=16 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/architecture_and_design/article2125027.ece |title= St Pancras regains the Gothic glamour |date= 24 July 2007 |last= Dyckhoff |first= Tom |work= The Times |location= London |accessdate=}}</ref>
It had originally been intended to retain some Eurostar services at [[Waterloo International railway station|Waterloo International]], but this was ruled out on cost grounds.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article2865114.ece |last= Webster |first= Ben
|title= Five Waterloo platforms left in limbo by Eurostar pullout |work= The Times |location= London |date= 14 November 2007 |accessdate=}}</ref>
Completion of High Speed 1 has increased the potential number of trains serving London. Separation of Eurostar from British domestic services through Kent meant that timetabling was no longer affected by peak-hour restrictions.

[[File:Eurostar at St Pancras Jan 2008.jpg|thumb|left|Eurostar trains in the renovated train shed at [[St Pancras International railway station|St Pancras International]]]]

{{Main|Juxtaposed controls}}

Because the UK is not part of the [[Schengen Area]],<ref name="Schengen">{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4738063.stm |title= Q&A: Schengen Agreement |work= BBC News |date =15 December 2008 |accessdate=26 April 2009}}</ref> and because Belgium and France are not part of the [[Common Travel Area]], all Eurostar passengers must go through border controls. Both the British Government and the Schengen governments concerned (Belgium and France) have legal obligations to check the travel documents of those entering their respective countries (as well as those leaving, in the case of Belgium and France).

To allow passengers to walk off the train without arrival checks in most cases, [[juxtaposed controls]] ordinarily take place at the embarkation station.

In order to comply with special UK legislation,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1994/570/contents/made |title=The Channel Tunnel (Security) Order 1994 (especially point 13) |publisher=Legislation.gov.uk |date=20 March 2012 |accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref> there are full security checks similar to those at airports, scanning both bags and people's pockets. Security checks at Eurostar are comparable to those at a small airport and generally much quicker than at London Heathrow.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://blog.firetree.net/2005/07/30/eurostar-security/|title=What is Eurostar Security for? |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref> The recommended check-in time is 30 minutes except for business class where it is 10 minutes.

Eurostar passengers travelling inside the [[Schengen Area]] (Brussels–Lille or Brussels–Calais; Lille–Calais trips are not allowed to be performed by Eurostar) pass through a separate corridor in Brussels bypassing border checks, and enter the preallocated cars of the train, which is reserved for these passengers. This arrangement was set up after numerous illegal immigrants entered the UK without the right to do so, by buying a ticket from Brussels to Lille or Calais but remaining on the train until London – an issue exacerbated by Belgian police threatening to arrest UK Border Agency staff at Brussels-Midi if they tried to prevent passengers whom they suspected of attempting to exploit this loophole from boarding Eurostar trains.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16058860|title=UK border staff in arrest threat over 'Lille loophole'|first=Simon|last=Cox|date=8 December 2011|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>

When the tripartite agreements were signed, the [[Belgian federal government|Belgian Government]] said that it had serious questions about the compatibility of this agreement with the Schengen Convention and the principle of free movement of people enshrined in various European Treaties.<ref>{{Link language|fr}} [http://www.senaat.be/www/?MIval=/publications/viewPub&COLL=S&LEG=1&NR=396&PUID=16778954&LANG=fr Document législatif du Sénat belge n°1-396/1, Déclarations du Gouvernement belge], 23 July 1996</ref>
On 30 June 2009 Eurostar raised concerns at the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|UK House of Commons]] Home Affairs Select Committee that it was illegal under French law for the collection of information desired by the UK government under the [[Border control|e-Borders]] scheme, and they would be unable to cooperate.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6610209.ece
|title=New British £750 million electronic border control plan 'breaks EU law'
|work = The Times | location = London
 |last=Ford |first=Richard
 |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/06/30/eborders_eurostar
|title=Eurostar tunnels through UK border ring of steel |work = [[The Register]]
|last=Williams |first=Chris |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2009}}</ref>

On the northbound Marne la Vallée-Chessy - London train, the security check and French passport check take place at Marne la Vallée-Chessy, while the UK passport check takes place at the UK arrival stations - this is the only route where passengers are not cleared by UK border officials before crossing the channel.

On the northbound Marseille-London train, there is no facility for security or passport checks at the southern French stations, so passengers must leave the train at Lille-Europe, taking all their belongings with them, and undergo security and border checks there before rejoining the train which waits at the station for just over an hour.<ref name="dowd-bbc-052015">{{cite web|last1=Dowd|first1=Vincent|title=Direct train to Europe|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-32916197|publisher=BBC World Service|accessdate=30 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530091011/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-32916197|archivedate=30 May 2015|date=30 May 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>

On several occasions, people have illegally tried to stow away on board the train,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1173533/Migration-Impossible-Illegal-immigrant-clings-roof-186mph-Eurostar-desperate-bid-enter-Britain.html
|title=Immigrant clings to roof of 186mph Eurostar |work = Daily Mail | location = London |last=Boffey |first=Daniel |date=25 April 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/14/magazine/the-light-at-the-end-of-the-chunnel.html?pagewanted=1
|title=The Light at The End of the Chunnel |work = The New York Times
|last=Landesman |first=Peter |date=14 April 2002 |accessdate=26 April 2009}}</ref> sometimes in large groups,<ref>{{cite news |date=3 August 2001 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1472136.stm |title=Police find Eurostar stowaways |work =BBC News |accessdate=26 April 2009}}</ref> trying to enter the UK; border monitoring and security is therefore extremely tight.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurotunnel.com/ukcP3Main/ukcFreight/ukcsafetysecurity/ukpbordercontrols.htm |title=Safety and security: Border controls |publisher= Eurotunnel |accessdate=1 September 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125163402/http://www.eurotunnel.com/ukcP3Main/ukcFreight/ukcsafetysecurity/ukpbordercontrols.htm|archivedate=25 November 2010}}</ref>
Eurostar claims to have good and well-funded security measures.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/about_eurostar/press_release/press_archive_2007/Eurostar_boosts_passenger_security.jsp |date=6 June 2007 |title=Eurostar boosts passenger security at Ashford International |publisher=Eurostar |accessdate=<!----26 April 2009----> |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029110659/http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/about_eurostar/press_release/press_archive_2007/Eurostar_boosts_passenger_security.jsp |archive-date=29 October 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

Passengers in general, it stated, are becoming increasingly aware of the environmental effects of air travel, and Eurostar services emit much less [[carbon dioxide]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/travel_information/before_you_go/Green_Eurostar.jsp |title= Eurostar generates ten times less CO<sub>2</sub> than flying the same routes |publisher= Eurostar |accessdate= 1 September 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090826113148/http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/travel_information/before_you_go/Green_Eurostar.jsp |archive-date= 26 August 2009 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> and that its remaining carbon emissions are now [[Carbon offset|offset]], making its services [[carbon neutral]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/6562391.stm |title= Eurostar plans 'greener' trains |date= 17 April 2007 |work= BBC News |accessdate=26 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Lane |url=http://www.ttglive.com/c/portal/layout?p_l_id=61139&CMPI_SHARED_articleId=2406032&CMPI_SHARED_ImageArticleId=2406032&CMPI_SHARED_articleIdRelated=2406032&CMPI_SHARED_ToolsArticleId=2406032&CMPI_SHARED_CommentArticleId=2406032&articleTitle=Eurostar%20reports%2031%%20fall%20in%20CO2%20emissions |date=28 April 2009 |location=London |title=Eurostar reports 31% fall in CO<sub>2</sub> emissions |work=Travel Trade Gazette |accessdate=29 April 2009 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Further expansion of the high-speed rail network in Europe, such as the [[HSL-Zuid]] line between Belgium and the Netherlands, continues to bring more destinations within rail-competitive range, giving Eurostar the possibility of opening up new services in future.

===Awards and accolades===
[[File:Eurostar trainsets at Paris Nord.jpg|thumb|right|Several Eurostar trains at platforms at Paris Gare du Nord]]
[[File:DSC 7230-voies-de-la-gare-d.jpg|thumb|right|Eurostars at Paris [[Gare du Nord]] running late night services]]
Eurostar has been hailed as having set new standards in international rail travel and has won praise several times over, recognising its high standards.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.jrtr.net/jrtr40/pdf/f29_eur.pdf
|title= Eurostar — A seamless journey to the continent
|journal=Japan Railway & Transport Review |volume=40 |date=March 2005 |pages=29–33 |accessdate=1 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/citybreaks/738818/Eurostar-welcome-to-the-new-age-of-trains.html
|title= Eurostar: welcome to the new age of trains |last=Davidson |first=Max |work=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |date=14 November 2007 |accessdate=2 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/about_eurostar/company_information/awards.jsp |title= Eurostar Company Awards page |publisher= Eurostar |accessdate= 11 May 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090528043914/http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/about_eurostar/company_information/awards.jsp |archive-date= 28 May 2009 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Eurostar won the [[Train Operator of the Year]] award in the [[HSBC]] Rail Awards for 2005.<ref name="bahneuroally"/> It was declared the Best Train Company in the joint [[The Guardian|Guardian]]/[[The Observer|Observer]] Travel Awards 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2008/oct/12/travel-awards2008?page=all |title= Travel Awards 2008 winners |date=12 October 2008 |work = The Guardian |location= London |accessdate=1 May 2009}}</ref> Eurostar had previously struggled with its reputation and brand image. One commentator had defined the situation at the time as:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/human-resources/workforce-management/1061023-1.html |title=Rebuilding Eurostar's brand and reputation |first=Paul |last=Charles |issn=1363-9064 |work=Strategic Communication Management |date=1 June 2005 |location=Chicago & London |accessdate=7 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225173448/http://www.allbusiness.com/human-resources/workforce-management/1061023-1.html |archivedate=25 February 2010 }}</ref>
{{quote |In June 2003, Eurostar was battling to recover from the worst period in its 10-year history. Negative media coverage combined with poor sales and the general public's low opinion of the British rail industry, created a major challenge... Eurostar was finding it difficult to pick itself up from one of the worst periods in its decade-long history. The period post [[September 11 attacks|9/11]] had sent the business into a downturn. Passenger numbers were drying up due to worries over international travel. Several management changes had led to a pause in strategy. Punctuality had suffered badly because of wider problems with the UK's rail infrastructure.}}
By 2008, Eurostar's environmental credentials had become highly developed and promoted.<ref>{{cite book |author= Grant, John |publisher = John Wiley |year= 2008 |location= Chichester, Sussex
|title= The green marketing manifesto |page = 94 |isbn= 0-470-72324-6}}</ref> In 2006 Eurostar's Environment Group was set up,<ref name="greennetrail">{{cite web|url=http://www.networkrail.co.uk/aspx/4681.aspx |title=Winners of 2007 |publisher=[[Network Rail]] |accessdate=7 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106195310/http://www.networkrail.co.uk/aspx/4681.aspx |archivedate=6 January 2009 }}</ref> with the aim of making changes in the Eurostar services' daily running to decrease the environmental impact, the organisation setting itself a target of reducing carbon emissions per passenger journey by 25% by 2012.<ref name = 'greeneuro'>{{cite news |url= http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/05/french-nuclear-power-cleans-up-eurostar |last= Kanter |first= James |title= French Nuclear Power Cleans Up Eurostar |work = Green Inc. blog |publisher=The New York Times |date=5 May 2009 |accessdate=8 May 2009}}</ref> Drivers are trained in techniques to achieve maximum energy efficiency, and lighting has been minimised; the provider of the bulk of the energy for the Channel Tunnel has been switched to nuclear power stations in France.<ref name = 'greeneuro'/>
{{Update|section|date=June 2014|cat=Rail transport articles in need of updating}}
Eurostar's current target is to reduce emissions by 35 percent per passenger journey by 2012, putting itself beyond the efforts of other railway companies in this field and thereby winning the 2007 [[Network Rail]] Efficiency Award.<ref name="greennetrail"/>
In the grand opening ceremony of St Pancras International, one of the Eurostar trains was given the name 'Tread Lightly', said to symbolise their smaller impact on the environment compared to planes.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JE9g55KMEQ4&feature=channel Statement by Richard Brown, Chief Executive of Eurostar, during the opening ceremony], video clip on YouTube.</ref>

Eurostar is a member of [[Railteam]], a marketing alliance formed in July 2007 of seven European [[high-speed rail]] operators.<ref name="highspeedrev">{{cite news

===Current fleet===

====Class 373====
[[File:Rame Eurostar en Savoie.JPG|thumb|right|Eurostar in [[Savoie]], in the [[French Alps]]]]
[[File:Eurostar trains at St Pancras.jpg|thumb|right|Three Eurostar trains waiting at [[St Pancras railway station|St Pancras station]]]]
{{main |British Rail Class 373}}
Built between 1992 and 1996, Eurostar's fleet consists of 38 [[Electric Multiple Unit|EMU]] trains, designated Class 373 in the United Kingdom and TGV TMST in France. The units have also been branded as the Eurostar e300 by Eurostar since 2015. There are two variants:
* 31 "Inter-Capital" sets consisting of two [[power car]]s and eighteen passenger carriages. These trains are {{convert|394|m}} long and can carry 750 passengers: 206 in first class, 544 in standard class.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.raileurope.co.uk/DOCUMENTS/PDFS/TRAIN%20SEATING%20PLANS/EUROSTAR/EUROSTAR%20SEATING%20PLAN.PDF
|title=Eurostar seating plan |work=RailEurope.com |accessdate=30 April 2007}}</ref>
* 7 shorter "North of London" sets which have two [[power car]]s and fourteen passenger carriages and are {{convert|320|m}} long. These sets have a capacity of 558 seats: 114 first class, 444 standard and which were designed to operate the aborted [[Regional Eurostar]] services.

The trains are essentially modified [[TGV]] sets,<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.jrtr.net/jrtr03/pdf/f17_ell.pdf |title= High speed for Europe
|date = October 1994
|author1=Wilckens, Martin |author2=Ellewanger, Gunther |work =Japan Railway & Transport Review |accessdate=1 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.dgcis.gouv.fr/files/files/directions_services/secteurs-professionnels/etudes/ferrogb.pdf
 |title=French Railway Industry: The paths of excellence
 |publisher=DGE/[[UBIFRANCE]]
 |accessdate=6 January 2014
 |deadurl=yes
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106201921/http://www.dgcis.gouv.fr/files/files/directions_services/secteurs-professionnels/etudes/ferrogb.pdf
 |archivedate=6 January 2014
 |df=
}}</ref> and can operate at up to {{convert|300|km/h|mph|0}} on high-speed lines, and {{convert|160|km/h|mph|0}} in the Channel Tunnel.<ref name = 'railfaneurostar'/><ref name="eurotunnrules" /> It is possible to exceed the 300-kilometre-per-hour speed limit, but only with special permission from the safety authorities in the respective country.<ref>{{cite news
|url= https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2007/09/05/eurostar-sets-new-paris-london-record-115875-19736230/
|title= Eurostar sets new Paris-London record |date=5 September 2007 |first=Emily |last=Nash |work = The Mirror | location = London |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref>
Speed limits in the Channel Tunnel are dictated by air-resistance, energy (heat) dissipation and the need to fit in with other, slower trains. The trains were designed with Channel Tunnel safety in mind, and consist of two independent "half-sets" each with its own power car.<ref name="CTRLrailtec"/><ref name="eurotunnrules" /> In the event of a serious fire on board while travelling through the tunnel, passengers would be transferred into the undamaged half of the train, which would then be detached and driven out of the tunnel to safety.<ref name = 'highspeedwho'>{{cite news
|url=http://www.christianwolmar.co.uk/2007/11/rail-579-who-is-going-to-use-the-new-high-speed-line/
|title= Who is going to use the new high speed line? |issue=579
|date=23 November 2007 |first=Christian |last=Wolmar |authorlink=Christian Wolmar
|work = Rail | location = Peterborough |accessdate=11 May 2009}}</ref>
If the undamaged part were the rear half of the train, this would be driven by the Chef du Train, who is a fully authorised driver and occupies the rear driving cab while the train travels through the tunnel for this purpose.<ref>{{cite news
|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/3531375/Eurostar-services-could-be-disrupted-by-strike-in-run-up-to-Christmas.html
|title= Eurostar services could be disrupted by strike in run up to Christmas
| date=27 November 2008 |first=David |last=Millward | work = The Daily Telegraph
| location = London |accessdate=11 May 2009}}</ref>

As 27 of the 31 Inter-Capital sets are sufficient to operate the service, four are currently used by SNCF for domestic TGV services; one of these regularly operates a Paris–Lille shuttle. The Eurostar logos have been removed from these sets, but the base colours of white, black, and yellow remain. SNCF's lease of the sets is scheduled to last until 2011{{update inline|date=February 2014}}, with an option for a further two years.<ref>{{cite news
| url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article2033855.ece
|last= Webster |first= Ben
|title = Trains for high-speed link handed over to the French
|work=The Times |location = London |date = 6 July 2007 |accessdate =9 April 2009}}</ref>

Each train has a unique four-digit number starting with "3" (3xxx). This designates the train as a Mark 3 TGV (Mark 1 being [[SNCF TGV Sud-Est]]; Mark 2 being [[SNCF TGV Atlantique]]). The second digit denotes the country of ownership:
* 3'''0'''xx UK
* 3'''1'''xx Belgium
* 3'''2'''xx France
* 3'''3'''xx Regional Eurostar

=====Fleet updates=====
[[File:Eurostar Leisure Select Seats.jpg|thumb|left|Interior of a ''Leisure Select'' Eurostar carriage]]
In 2004–2005 the "Inter-Capital" sets still in daily use for international services were refurbished with a new interior designed by [[Philippe Starck]].<ref name="Eurost His"/><ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/2940864.stm |title=Multi-million facelift for Eurostar |work= BBC News |date=27 May 2003 |accessdate=27 December 2007}}</ref>
The original grey-yellow scheme in Standard class and grey-red of First/Premium First were replaced with a grey-brown look in Standard and grey-burnt-orange in First class. Power points were added to seats in First class and coaches 5 and 14 in Standard class. Premium First class was renamed BusinessPremier.

In 2008, Eurostar announced that it would be carrying out a mid-life refurbishment of its Class 373 trains to allow the fleet to remain in service beyond 2020.<ref>{{cite news
|url= http://viking.eukhost.com/~keepingt/rm/162/RMAN_162.pdf |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090620081818/http://viking.eukhost.com/~keepingt/rm/162/RMAN_162.pdf |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 20 June 2009 |title=Eurostar invites bidders to undertake major interior refurbishment of fleet |date=8 September 2008 |work=Rail Management |location = Dunstable, Beds. |page=5}}</ref>
This will include the 28 units making up the Eurostar fleet, but not the three Class 373/1 units used by SNCF or the seven Class 373/2 "North of London" sets.<ref>{{cite news |title= Eurostar to tender for refurbishment |work = RailNews |date=8 September 2008  |url= http://www.railnews.co.uk/news/2008/09/08-eurostar-refurbishment.html |location= London |accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>
As part of the refurbishment, the Italian company [[Pininfarina]] was contracted to redesign the interiors,<ref>{{cite news |url =http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/single-view/view//eurostar-refurbishment-design-contract-awarded.html |title =Eurostar refurbishment design contract awarded |location =London |work =[[Railway Gazette International]] |date =8 April 2009 |accessdate =9 April 2009 |deadurl =yes |archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120414235334/http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/single-view/view/eurostar-refurbishment-design-contract-awarded.html |archivedate =14 April 2012 |df =dmy-all }}</ref> and The Yard Creative was selected to design the new buffet cars.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.designweek.co.uk/the-yard-creates-drastically-different-eurostar-buffet-cars/3000572.article |title= The Yard creates 'drastically different' Eurostar buffet cars
|work= Design Week |location= London |date=14 May 2009}}</ref>
On 11 May 2009 Eurostar revealed the new look for its first-class compartments.<ref>{{cite news
 |url          = http://news.opodo.co.uk/NewsDetails/2009-05-11/Eurostar_unveils_new_first_class_layout
 |title        = Eurostar unveils new first class layout
 |publisher    = Opodo Travel News
 |date         = 11 May 2009
 |access-date  = 7 April 2012
 |archive-url  = https://web.archive.org/web/20131230070457/http://news.opodo.co.uk/NewsDetails/2009-05-11/Eurostar_unveils_new_first_class_layout
 |archive-date = 30 December 2013
 |dead-url     = yes
 |df           = dmy-all
}}</ref>
The first refurbished train was due in service in 2012,<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/apr/09/eurostar-interiors-italian-design |title= Eurostar interiors to get makeover by Italian luxury car designer |work=The Guardian |location= London |date =9 April 2009 |first=Rebecca |last=Smithers |accessdate=1 April 2010}}</ref> and Eurostar plans to have completed the entire process by 2014.
{{clear}}

On 13 November 2014 Eurostar announced the first refurbished trains would not re-enter the fleet until the 3rd or 4th quarter of 2015 due to delays at the completion centre.<ref name="railwaygazette.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/news/europe/single-view/view/eurostar-orders-seven-more-e320s.html|title=Eurostar orders seven more e320s|first=DVV Media|last=UK|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref>

====Class 374====
{{main|British Rail Class 374}}
In addition to the announced mid-life update of the existing Class 373 fleet, Eurostar in 2009 reportedly entered prequalification bids for eight new trainsets to be purchased.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/single-view/view//eurostar-considering-larger-fleet.html
| title = Eurostar considering larger fleet?
| work = Railway Gazette International |location=London | date =6 April 2009 | accessdate = 18 April 2009}}</ref> Any new trains would need to meet the same safety rules governing passage through the Channel Tunnel as the existing Class 373 fleet. The replacement to the Class 373 trains has been decided jointly between the French Transport Ministry and the UK [[Department for Transport]].  The new trains will be equipped to use the new [[ERTMS]] in-cab signalling system, due to be fitted to High Speed 1 around 2040.<ref name='rmtbrist'>{{cite news
 |url=http://www.rmtbristol.org.uk/2007/10/2017_start_date_for_great_west.html
 |title=2017 start date for Great Western ERTMS upgrade
 |publisher=The National Union of Rail, Maritime & Transport workers (RMT)
 |date=9 October 2007
 |accessdate=8 September 2009
 |deadurl=yes
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226182631/http://www.rmtbristol.org.uk/2007/10/2017_start_date_for_great_west.html
 |archivedate=26 December 2007
 |df=
}}</ref>

[[File:Class 374 in Paris.jpg|thumb|Class 374 at [[Gare du Nord]] in Paris.]]
On 7 October 2010, it was reported that Eurostar had selected [[Siemens]] as preferred bidder to supply 10 [[Siemens Velaro]]  e320<ref name=rgi320kmhtrains /> trainsets at a cost of €600 million (and a total investment of more than £700 million with the refurbishment of the existing fleet included)<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11491048 |work= BBC News |title= Eurostar unveils £700m train deal |date=7 October 2010}}</ref> to operate an expanded route network, including services from London to [[Cologne]] and [[Amsterdam]].<ref name=rgi20101001>{{cite news |url= http://www.railwaygazette.com/nc/news/single-view/view/eurostar-picks-velaro-to-expand-fleet.html |title=Eurostar picks Velaro to expand fleet |work= Railway Gazette International |location =London  |date=1 October 2010 |accessdate=2 October 2010}}</ref> These would be sixteen-car, {{convert|400|m|ft|0|adj=on}} long trainsets built to meet current Channel Tunnel regulations.<ref name=rgi20101001 /> The top speed will be {{Convert|320|km/h|0|abbr=on}} and they will have 894–950 seats, unlike the current fleet built by the French company [[Alstom]], which has a top speed of {{Convert|300|km/h|0|abbr=on}} and a seating capacity of 750. Total traction power will be rated at 16 MW.<ref name=rgi320kmhtrains>{{cite web | url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/nc/news/single-view/view/320-kmh-train-order-as-eurostar-sets-sights-on-expansion.html | title=320 km/h train order as Eurostar sets sights on expansion |work= Railway Gazette International |location =London |date=7 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.siliconrepublic.com/green-tech/item/18446-carbon-efficient-eurostar/ |work= Silicon Republic |title= Carbon efficient Eurostar fleet going green |date=21 October 2010 |location =Dublin}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.railjournal.com/newsflash/siemens-weathering-economic-storm-as-work-begins-on-new-eurostar-1375.html |title=Siemens weathering economic storm as work begins on new Eurostar |work=International Railway Journal |location=London |date=31 October 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319012931/http://www.railjournal.com/newsflash/siemens-weathering-economic-storm-as-work-begins-on-new-eurostar-1375.html |archivedate=19 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mobility.siemens.com/apps/references/index.cfm?z=1&do=app.detail&referenceID=1718&lID=1 |title=Siemens Mobility References |publisher=Siemens |year=2011 |accessdate=7 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524131015/http://www.mobility.siemens.com/apps/references/index.cfm?z=1&do=app.detail&referenceID=1718&lID=1 |archivedate=24 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

The nomination of Siemens would see it break into the French high-speed market for the first time, as all French and French subsidiary high-speed operators use TGV derivatives produced by [[Alstom]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5696688c-cd4c-11df-ab20-00144feab49a.html?ftcamp=rss |title= Row breaks out over Eurostar train order |newspaper= Financial Times |location= London |last=Wright |first= Robert |date=1 October 2010 |accessdate=1 October 2010}}</ref> Alstom attempted legal action to prevent Eurostar from acquiring German-built trains, claiming that the Siemens sets ordered would breach Channel Tunnel safety rules,<ref>{{cite news |title= Alstom heads for court over Eurostar trains |newspaper= Financial Times | location = London | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d9258852-db64-11df-ae99-00144feabdc0.html |first= Robert |last= Wright |date=19 October 2010}}</ref> but this was thrown out of court.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.railjournal.com/newsflash/alstom-fails-to-block-eurostar-contract.html |accessdate=30 October 2010 |title=Alstom fails to block Eurostar contract |work= International Railway Journal |date=30 October 2010 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101101061536/http://www.railjournal.com/newsflash/alstom-fails-to-block-eurostar-contract.html |archivedate=1 November 2010 |location =London}}</ref> Alstom said, after its High Court defeat, that it would "pursue alternative legal options to uphold its position". On 4 November 2010, the company lodged a complaint with the [[European Commission]] over the tendering process, which then asked the British government for "clarification".<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/30191634-e843-11df-8995-00144feab49a.html#axzz14zoLF4h2|accessdate=11 November 2010 |title= Alstom lodges Eurostar complaint in Brussels |work= Financial Times |location=London |date= 4 November 2010}}</ref> Alstom then announced it had started legal action against Eurostar, again in the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] in London.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE6AA1T720101111|accessdate=11 November 2010
|title=Alstom says Eurostar tender hearing in Oct 2011 |work= Reuters |date=11 November 2010 |first=Astrid |last=Wendlandt}}</ref>
In July 2011, the High Court rejected Alstom's claim that the tender process was "ineffective",<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/jul/14/siemens-keeps-eurostar-order-from-alstom |accessdate=15 August 2012 |title=Siemens keeps €600m Eurostar order after Alstom legal challenge fails |work= The Guardian |location =London |date=15 July 2011 |page=29 |first=Dan |last=Milmo}}</ref> and in April 2012 Alstom said it would call off pending court actions against Siemens.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2012/apr/02/eurostar-siemens |accessdate=15 August 2012 |title= Alstom drops Eurostar legal action after SNCF orders more trains |work= The Guardian |location =London |date=3 April 2012 |first=Gwyn |last=Topham}}</ref> This effectively freed the way for Siemens to build the new Eurostar trains,<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.railway-technology.com/features/featurebetter-by-design-eurostars-700-million-facelift |accessdate=23 September 2012 |title=Better by design: Eurostar's £700m facelift |work= railway-technology.com |date=12 March 2012 }}</ref> the first of which were expected to enter service in late 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/nov/13/eurostar-e320-launch-st-pancras-20-percent-more-passengers-900-people|title=Eurostar launches e320 train with space for 900 passengers|first1=Rebecca|last1=Smithers|first2=Gwyn|last2=Topham|work=The Guardian|date=13 November 2014|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>{{clarify|date=January 2018}}

On 13 November 2014 Eurostar announced the purchase of an additional seven e320s for delivery in the second half of 2016. At the same time, Eurostar announced the first five e320s from the original order of ten would be available by December 2015, with the remaining five entering service by May 2016. Of the five sets ready by December 2015, three of them were planned to be used on London-Paris and London-Brussels routes.<ref name="railwaygazette.com"/>
